;在 18 世纪的法国和中国检测到与蓝色相关或不相关的砷基遮光剂珐琅工艺品。最具代表性的拉曼签名与之前在“参考”阶段发布的拉曼签名进行了分类。最相关的 PCA 分类是通过利用从光谱分解中提取的参数来获得的，这允许识别至少四种类型的拉曼特征和结构。

;摘要

;

;拉曼分析是一种非侵入性技术，可以通过移动系统在现场进行。然而，牙釉质中不同数量的不同晶相或无定形相（玻璃基质、遮光剂和颜料）的存在导致拉曼特征的部分观察，这些特征通常没有在文献中被表征。我们在这里研究 18 世纪法国和中国物品的白色、蓝色和黄/绿色珐琅中观察到的相，并比较固态光谱方法的有效性（确定与结构相关的振动模式的参数） ）和多元化学计量方法（PCA 和层次聚类），对全局或部分光谱或从第一种方法提取的参数进行。将文献中的相邻或相似相的光谱合并到处理数据的语料库中，特别是那些最初没有结构特征的相所获得的光谱，对于结果的质量是决定性的。至少鉴定出四种不同的砷化铅。峰的目视观察和多变量分析相结合表明，与 820 cm;-1; 附近主要 As-O 伸缩振动相关的能带的形状、位置和面积根据与某些作坊特有的生产技术。与光谱参数的检查相比，仅基于光谱的多变量分析的贡献似乎非常有限。

;摘要

;嵌入基序 (iM) 是一种四链结构，由半质子化的 CC;+; 对形成的两个平行同源双链体组成，插层彼此反平行。 iM 通常在酸性 pH 下形成，因为其形成需要胞嘧啶质子化。然而，具有长胞嘧啶束的序列可以在生理pH条件下形成iM。在这里，我们使用非共振拉曼和紫外共振拉曼（使用同步辐射）光谱 (RS) 来研究序列 (C;9;T;3;); 3;C;9;，最近已通过其他光谱方法（CD、;1;H NMR）进行了彻底分析。根据这些方法，RS 表明 (C;9;T;3;);3;C;9; 采用 iM中性 pH 值和 iM 的形成动力学缓慢，分多个步骤熔化，并且在折叠和重折叠过程之间表现出较大的热滞后。温度相关拉曼光谱中等吸光点的存在（与 SVD 分析一致，表明仅两个独立的光谱分量）表明 (C;9;T;3;)< sub>;3;C;9; 被发现是无序和有序结构的混合物，其比例取决于温度。有序的 iM 种类被认为由相同类型的 CC;+; 对组成，但其数量和沿胞嘧啶束的排列不同。相关序列 (C;9;A;3;);3;C;9; 显示与 (C; 9;T;3;);3;C;9;，说明腺嘌呤碱基取代胸腺嘧啶碱基影响不大。

;碳材料呈现出独特的拉曼特征，该特征取决于各种因素，包括主要的碳杂化。获得了多种碳材料的参考光谱，并将其用作机器学习算法的训练集。该程序可以对文献中报道的拉曼光谱库进行自动分类，准确度很高（97%）。

;
;

;摘要

;

;主成分分析（PCA）和线性判别分析（LDA）用于根据拉曼光谱对不同类型的碳材料进行分类。所选参考材料为高取向热解石墨（HOPG）、类金刚石碳（DLC）、玻璃碳（GC）、氢化类石墨碳（GLCH）和氢化类聚合物碳（PLCH）。这些材料的结晶度、主要碳杂化和氢含量各不相同。训练数据集是从商业样品（HOPG、DLC、GC）和我们实验室合成的样品（GLCH、PLCH）收集的拉曼光谱。使用 532 nm 激光激发收集拉曼光谱。分类模型表明，第一主成分 (PC1) 是从无定形碳样品中分离晶体的决定性信息来源。 PC2 允许分离具有不同杂化程度的非晶材料（sp;2; 和 sp;3;）。最后，PC2 和 PC3 都有助于分离具有不同氢化程度的材料。使用文献报道的碳材料拉曼光谱库对分类模型进行了测试，结果显示预测准确度很高（97％）。这里介绍的模型为使用拉曼光谱和机器学习对碳材料进行自动分类提供了途径。

We show that the optimization of the laser photon energy provides (for at least one of the chosen excitation wavelengths) high‐end quality Raman spectra for each examined sample. In most cases, the infrared spectral range is advanced for biological samples, while an excitation in the visible and ultraviolet spectral range is often favorable or at least sufficient for accurate identification/resolution of mineral phases under the illuminated laser spot on the planetary surface simulants. Ultraviolet excitation does not always deliver significant contrast of the Raman Stokes responses to the induced photoluminescence in the studied biomolecules. Most prominent features in the Raman spectra of the biological samples are assigned to their specific pigments, also considered as biomolecular signatures of the extremophiles. The critical issue of specific advantages and limitations of each particular excitation source implies study for gaining scientific return from Raman spectroscopy for exobiological prospecting, for instance, the best trade between a single or dual excitation wavelength(s) for both biological and geological spectral data. ;

;This study confirms the critical importance of a choice of an appropriate wavelength of an excitation laser for avoiding/reduction of photoluminescence in Raman scattering spectroscopy and by this achieving the best possible contrast of Raman signatures for strongly luminescent biological samples and mineral mixes simulating planetary surface regolith, relevant to astrobiology. Infrared excitation is primarily desired for the best performance for biological molecules, offering not only a low-PL response but also a low potential damage than the short-wavelength lasers. Identification of mineral phases is feasible in the entire UV-NIR range, while a green laser with a combination of a silicon-based CCD offers the best signal-to-noise and can return, therefore, reasonable Raman signals at relatively low laser intensity.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;We investigated the potential of a laser selection in the broad optical range, from ultraviolet through visible to infrared (excitation wavelengths of 325, 532, 785, and 1064 nm) for combined analysis of Earth-relevant extremophiles (;Xanthoria elegans;, ;Buellia frigida;, and ;green alga of Circinaria gyrosa;), ;carbohydrate; molecules, as well as Mars and Moon surface regolith simulants as analog mineral mixtures (;P-MRS;, ;S-MRS, LRS,; and ;JSC-1;). We show that the optimization of the laser photon energy provides (for at least one of the chosen excitation wavelengths) high-end quality Raman spectra for each examined sample. In most cases, the infrared spectral range is advanced for biological samples, while an excitation in the visible and ultraviolet spectral range is often favorable or at least sufficient for accurate identification/resolution of mineral phases under the illuminated laser spot on the planetary surface simulants. Ultraviolet excitation does not always deliver significant contrast of the Raman Stokes responses to the induced photoluminescence in the studied biomolecules. Most prominent features in the Raman spectra of the biological samples are assigned to their specific pigments, also considered as ;biomolecular; signatures of the extremophiles. The critical issue of specific advantages and limitations of each particular excitation source implies study for gaining scientific return from Raman spectroscopy for exobiological prospecting, for instance, the best trade between a single or dual excitation wavelength(s) for both ;biological; and ;geological; spectral data.

Stand‐off Raman spectroscopy, in conjunction with chemometrics, was employed to detect and identify bloodstains from a distance. Bloodstain spectra were acquired using a handheld spectrometer equipped with a stand‐off attachment and compared to those obtained with a benchtop Raman microscope. Abstract Stand‐off Raman spectroscopy combined with chemometrics was demonstrated to have great potential for detecting and identifying biological stains from a distance for forensic purposes. Bloodstain spectra were collected using a handheld Raman spectrometer equipped with a stand‐off attachment and compared with spectra acquired with a benchtop Raman microscope. The two sets of spectra were visually similar, supporting the potential use of a handheld Raman spectrometer with stand‐off attachment for blood detection at the scene of crime. In addition, the stand‐off Raman spectra of bloodstains were correctly identified using a previously built SVM‐DA model for the identification of all main body fluids (Muro et al., Forensic Chemistry, 2016). Stand‐off Raman spectroscopy opens a new potential opportunity for further development of Raman spectroscopy as a universal tool for detecting and identifying body fluid traces for forensic purposes. ;

;Abstract

;

;Stand-off Raman spectroscopy combined with chemometrics was demonstrated to have great potential for detecting and identifying biological stains from a distance for forensic purposes. Bloodstain spectra were collected using a handheld Raman spectrometer equipped with a stand-off attachment and compared with spectra acquired with a benchtop Raman microscope. The two sets of spectra were visually similar, supporting the potential use of a handheld Raman spectrometer with stand-off attachment for blood detection at the scene of crime. In addition, the stand-off Raman spectra of bloodstains were correctly identified using a previously built SVM-DA model for the identification of all main body fluids (Muro et al., Forensic Chemistry, 2016). Stand-off Raman spectroscopy opens a new potential opportunity for further development of Raman spectroscopy as a universal tool for detecting and identifying body fluid traces for forensic purposes.

Advanced micro‐Raman techniques are used to investigate the intimate structure of microcapsules containing terpenoid mixtures as well as to characterize their effective encapsulation. Au nanostars are used as surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) labels to resolve the layered structure of the microcapsules due to 3D confocal Raman imaging. Abstract Terpenoids play a major role in agriculture, given their fungicidal and herbicidal actions, as well as their favorable toxicological, ecotoxicological, and environmental profiles. Despite all these advantages, terpenoids are reported to be unstable in direct sunlight and atmospheric conditions, so both commercial suppliers and scientific literature foresee their protection by encapsulation. The so‐called microcapsules (μCaps) are therefore of high relevance as drug‐delivery vectors, but very few techniques focus on their surface as well as on their morphological characterization. Indeed, these aspects are of great importance, given that their surface chemistry governs both their colloidal stability and mechanism of action. Common analysis techniques, such as chromatographic and mass‐spectrometric ones, are destructive, require sample preparation, and do not result in the complete morphological characterization of the microcapsules. Micro‐Raman spectroscopy, in conjunction with the surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) effect, offers a valuable alternative method of investigation capable of achieving a complete and non‐destructive morphological characterization of the terpenoid‐encapsulating systems, the dimensions of which fall within the micrometric range. In addition, the SERS effect can be exploited by fabricating the microcapsules with gold nanostars (AuNSs) modified with chitosan and a SERS reporter (Nile Blue A). Thanks to the high contrast provided by the SERS signals of this tag, it was possible to localize and confirm the chitosan in the morphology of the microcapsules. The results of this study shed new light on the possibility of analyzing terpenoid‐encapsulating microcapsules and possibly other kinds of encapsulates brought by using Raman spectroscopy and by exploiting the SERS effect. ;

;Abstract

;

;Terpenoids play a major role in agriculture, given their fungicidal and herbicidal actions, as well as their favorable toxicological, ecotoxicological, and environmental profiles. Despite all these advantages, terpenoids are reported to be unstable in direct sunlight and atmospheric conditions, so both commercial suppliers and scientific literature foresee their protection by encapsulation. The so-called microcapsules (;μ;Caps) are therefore of high relevance as drug-delivery vectors, but very few techniques focus on their surface as well as on their morphological characterization. Indeed, these aspects are of great importance, given that their surface chemistry governs both their colloidal stability and mechanism of action. Common analysis techniques, such as chromatographic and mass-spectrometric ones, are destructive, require sample preparation, and do not result in the complete morphological characterization of the microcapsules. Micro-Raman spectroscopy, in conjunction with the surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) effect, offers a valuable alternative method of investigation capable of achieving a complete and non-destructive morphological characterization of the terpenoid-encapsulating systems, the dimensions of which fall within the micrometric range. In addition, the SERS effect can be exploited by fabricating the microcapsules with gold nanostars (AuNSs) modified with chitosan and a SERS reporter (Nile Blue A). Thanks to the high contrast provided by the SERS signals of this tag, it was possible to localize and confirm the chitosan in the morphology of the microcapsules. The results of this study shed new light on the possibility of analyzing terpenoid-encapsulating microcapsules and possibly other kinds of encapsulates brought by using Raman spectroscopy and by exploiting the SERS effect.

Abstract We demonstrate the application of high‐resolution quasi‐continuous (q‐cw) stimulated Raman spectroscopy (SRS) to the study of low‐frequency, pure rotational transitions of molecules in diluted samples in order to obtain collisional information. The main problems encountered in the few pioneering q‐cw SRS rotational works, namely weak signals because of the small population differences between the upper and lower states of the transitions and the presence of alternating current (AC) Stark effect, have been addressed: technical improvements in the optical elements that perform the beam mixing, separation, and filtering have allowed us to use a collinear beam geometry and a triple pass configuration to enhance the Raman signals. The distortions in the line profiles caused by AC Stark effect have been measured and included in the numerical treatment of the spectra. With these extended capabilities, we have been able to register stimulated Raman transitions with wavenumbers as low as ∼ 11.5 cm−1, corresponding to the S(0) pure rotational transition of the molecule of CO. We have applied the setup to the study of collisional broadening of CO rotational lines perturbed by H2 and have obtained broadening coefficients for lines from S(0) to S(20) at 77, 180, and 298 K. A comparison between these anisotropic coefficients and those obtained from IR rovibrational experiments shows excellent agreement.
